awd_abstract_narration:
Matching markets have an important role in the economy.  They determine such varied outcomes as which student goes to which college, who gets what job, and who buys what house.  Recent work on the theory of matching markets has been useful to the design of markets as well as for the repair of market failures.  Much of this work, however, has focused on the design and analysis of centralized matching markets.  Many matching markets are not fully centralized; for example, college admissions decisions in the United States are made by each individual institution on its own.  Furthermore, almost all of the centralized matching marekts are preceeded by decentralized opportunities for participants to match.  This award funds research on the game theory of these decentralized markets as well as lab experiments and a field study to identify the crucial elements that determine decentralized market outcomes.

The field study uses the newly developed theory to analyze a unique data set tracing the way a specific adoption agency matched adopting parents to domestic birth mothers.  The goal is to use these data to better understand the preferences of adoptive parents and birth mothers towards potential matches.  

Broader Impacts:  The theory and experiments will provide useful tools for improving the design of matching markets.  The field study gives crucial information for child advocates who are seeking to improve state-level policy towards adoption and foster care.

por.por_cntn:
Matching markets have an important role in the economy. They determine such varied outcomes as which student goes to what school, who gets which job, who marries whom, and who buys which house. Recent theoretical work on matching has been useful for the design of markets as well as for the repair of market failures. Much of this work, however, has focused on the design and analysis of static centralized markets. Nonetheless, many markets are not fully centralized (for instance, college admissions in the U.S., the market for law clerks, junior economists, and so on). Furthermore, almost all centralized markets are preceded by decentralized opportunities for participants to match. The work funded under this award developed a theoretical framework for studying such decentralized markets. It also produced an array of experiments as well as field studies aimed at identifying the crucial elements that determine decentralized market outcomes.   

There are three main directions that were pursued. First, theoretical work provided foundations for identifying environments in which market intervention, in the form of a centralized clearinghouse (such as that used by the National Medical Residents Program, or NMRP, in the US), would be particularly beneficial.   

Second, a sequence of experimental studies implemented matching markets in the lab. The new experimental platform was designed to complement a range of empirical studies of markets. It provided a controlled way to assess important factors determining outcomes in decentralized and centralized markets such as market complexity, the amount of interaction in the market, and the information available to market participants.   

The third direction involved the collection and analysis of a unique longitudinal data set tracing the matching protocol between adopting parents and domestic birth mothers. In the U.S., adoption is prevalent -- approximately 1.6 million, or 2.5%,of all children are adopted. Of these, 87% were born in the US and placed through the domestic adoption process. Consequently, adoption reforms are a topic of ongoing debate in both the domestic and international arenas. The data collected enabled the estimation of certain attributes that are desirable for parents participating in the adoption process, including gender, race, and age. It also fed into an additional stream of theoretical work introducing the design of optimal dynamic matching protocols. These protocols are useful for markets in which participants appear over time. They are relevant not only for the adoption environment, but also for organ donations and certain labor markets.
